results.title: Home alone. Home alone 2 = Lost in New York
results.creator_credit: Chris Colombus, John Hughes and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Home alone is one of the most successful comedies of the eighties and stars pint-sized hero Macaulay Culkin. In a chaotic frenzy to get to the airport on time, the McCallister family forget one thing - eight year old Kevin. When two bungling burglars attempt to break into the McCallister household, Kevin is left home alone to defend himself and his house. He outwits the burglars by waging war the only way he knows how, with outlandish, yet effective boyhood pranks. Cast includes Joe Pesci, Daniel Stern, John Heard and John Candy. In the sequel to “Home alone” it’s Kevin who manages to isolate himself from the rest of the family when he boards the wrong plane at Christmastime and finds himself in New York city. He’s not alone for long however, as he quickly befriends a pigeon-lady and, once again crosses paths with two well known dim witted criminals. Cast includes Joe Pesci, Daniel Stern and Brenda Fricker.

results.title: Home Alone 3
results.brief_description: 9-year-old Alex Pruitt is home alone with the chicken pox. Turns out, due to a mix-up among nefarious spies, Alex was given a toy car concealing a top-secret microchip. Now Alex must fend off the spies as they try break into his house to get it back.

results.title: Home Alone 2: Lost in New York
results.brief_description: Instead of flying to Florida with his folks, Kevin ends up alone in New York, where he gets a hotel room with his dad’s credit card—despite problems from a clerk and meddling bellboy. But when Kevin runs into his old nemeses, the Wet Bandits, he’s determined to foil their plans to rob a toy store on Christmas eve.

results.title: Home alone (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Chris Columbus, John Hughes and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: This is one of the most successful comedies of the eighties and stars pint-sized hero Macaulay Culkin. In a chaotic frenzy to get to the airport on time, the McCallister family forget one thing - eight year old Kevin. When two bungling burglars attempt to break into the McCallister household, Kevin is left home alone to defend himself and his house. He outwits the burglars by waging war the only way he knows how. A John Hughes film co-starring Joe Pesci, “Home alone” is a modern-day classic.

results.title: Home Alone
results.brief_description: Eight-year-old Kevin McCallister makes the most of the situation after his family unwittingly leaves him behind when they go on Christmas vacation. But when a pair of bungling burglars set their sights on Kevin’s house, the plucky kid stands ready to defend his territory. By planting booby traps galore, adorably mischievous Kevin stands his ground as his frantic mother attempts to race home before Christmas Day.

constellations_other.name: Colour and illusion
constellations_other.description: Exploring the science of colour, light, reflection and movement.

constellations_other.name: Neo-Noir
constellations_other.description: Blade Runner's retro-futurist setting lends it a timeless quality, while also connecting it to the past and the future.

recommendations.quote: This legendary Christmas film penned by John Hughes is one of the most quotable films in history. But it's not just a screwball kid's comedy about Kevin overcoming his fears, it's equally about maternal devotion and Catherine O'Hara's Kate McAllister quest to reunite with her son.

results.title: Home again
results.brief_description: Kat Hay provides her account of the Newcastle Floods of 2007, from the realisation that it was not an ordinary day to the feelings associated with returning home after everything was destroyed.

results.title: Home
results.creator_credit: Zephlyn Neilsen, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Home
results.brief_description: As a child home was just an illusion. Growing up, moving overseas, home became temperal and Australia became “just back home” and on returning home, nothing made sense - everything had changed. Perhaps my mother’s words that “home is where the heart is” says it all.
